subject: Gardening
title: Frogs and Toads in the Garden
description: One-minute skill: Frogs and Toads in the Garden.

hook.text: A toad sitting under your garden bench eats 3,000 insects per month. It doesn't need feeding or maintenance.

buildup.text: Frogs and toads eat slugs, flies, mosquitoes, beetles, and caterpillarsâ€”generalist predators with huge appetites.

discovery.text: Toads prefer to hunt at night in damp conditionsâ€”exactly when slugs are most active. Perfect natural timing.

twist.text: Amphibian populations are crashing globally. Gardens with small ponds are becoming critical local refuges.

climax.text: A small garden pond attracts frogs and toads that provide persistent pest control for the entire garden.

punchline.text: A tiny pond buys you a permanent pest control crew.

quiz.question: Why are gardens with ponds important for amphibian conservation?
options: Garden ponds are the only habitat where frogs can survive winter
Amphibian populations are declining globally and gardens are becoming critical refuges
Garden ponds produce the specific algae that tadpoles need to develop
